issue.title: Auto import in angular typescript is not working
issue.body:
- VSCode Version:
Version 1.29.1
Typescript 3.1.4

- OS Version:
macOS 10.14.1 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new angular app:
`ng new app`

2. Add new library:
`yarn add @datorama/akita`

3. Create session.model.ts:
```typescript
export interface Session {
  id: ID;
  firstName: string;
  lastName: string;
  token: string;
}
```
Auto import is not working. I get this error:

```
[ts] Cannot find name 'ID'. [2304]
any
```

Starting VSCode with `code --disable-extensions` didn't help :(

comment.body:
I've just tried insiders version on Windows 10. The problem is still there. Auto import is not picking up the installed packages.

`Cannot find name 'ID'.ts(2304)`

issue.title: Error hover semantic information should be rendered separate of error message
issue.body:
From @octref in #62159

> This is a regression on the diagnostics display.
> 
> 1.28:
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/47816972-b83d2e80-dd11-11e8-92ea-97763e51688e.png)
> 
> Insiders:
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/47817088-00f4e780-dd12-11e8-8b0c-2d45c561fbf4.png)
> 
> In both case, the diagnostics returned are:
> 
> ```js
> const diagnostics = {
>   code: "unknownProperties",
>   source: "css.lint.unknownProperties",
>   message: "Unknown property: 'foo1'"
> }
> ```

If we have access to semantic information we should render it much better. The message should come first. Then the source on a separate line, with a `Source:` label preceding it and in non-monospace font (since source should be a user-readable string like `CSS Lint`). Then, the code with the same style, but with monospace, since code is often a library/OS error code. Something like:

> `Unknown property: 'foo1'`
>
> **Source:** CSS Lint
> **Code:** `unknownProperties`

cc @sandy081  @ramya-rao-a @misolori

issue.title: Replace doesn't insert captures when finding multible lines
issue.body:
Issue Type: Bug If you search in files for regular expressions with capture it doesn't work when matching multible lines. Example: find = (x),[\n\s]*(y); replace = $2 - $1 will change: "x, y;" to: "y - x", so this works. but it will change: "x, y;" to: "$2 - $1". This is literally "$1" and "$2". issue.title: "Stage selected ranges" adds a revert of those changes to the next commit
issue.body:
I am not able to test with the insiders build as I don't have permission to install unauthorized software versions on my workstation here.

- VSCode Version: 1.29.1
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

(Since this seems to be kind of finicky, I've added more details about how I select things and so on than I would ordinarily provide.)

1. Change two different locations in a file.
1. Select the changed lines in one location (with the mouse) and choose **Git: Stage Selected Ranges** from the palette (I open it with Ctrl-Shift-P).
2. Fill in a commit message and commit the change by pressing Ctrl-Enter.
3. Click off the previous selection and select the other change. Again choose **Git: Stage Selected Ranges** from the palette. *Do not do anything else in between* (sometimes the issue does not occur if you do other things).
4. View the staged changes. In addition to the newly staged lines, an exact revert of the previous changes is present. This does get committed if you then commit, and it shows up in `git diff --cached`.

This happens pretty reliably, but only happened 75% of the times I was trying to reproduce it -- I assume I was doing something else in between or selecting something in a slightly different way the times it didn't happen.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

## Git output

VSCode appears to be doing a lot of extra stuff the second time!

On staging the first change:

```
> git show HEAD:git training/Activities/activities.md
> git hash-object --stdin -w --path git training/Activities/activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- git training/Activities/activities.md
> git update-index --cacheinfo 100644 3592ee3adb9657ed0ef318abc491cbc19969d7b5
 git training/Activities/activities.md
> git status -z -u
> git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
> git rev-parse pilot/master
> git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name pilot/master@{u}
> git rev-list --left-right pilot/master...refs/remotes/origin/pilot/master
> git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname) --sort -committerdate
> git remote --verbose
> git show :git training/Activities/activities.md
```

On staging the second change:

```
> git hash-object --stdin -w --path git training/Activities/activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- git training/Activities/activities.md
> git update-index --cacheinfo 100644 a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
 git training/Activities/activities.md
> git status -z -u
> git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
> git rev-parse pilot/master
> git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name pilot/master@{u}
> git rev-list --left-right pilot/master...refs/remotes/origin/pilot/master
> git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname) --sort -committerdate
> git remote --verbose
> git show :git training/Activities/activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git show 29fdbfdab2573936bf25f93dc9d00e36c3079920
> git ls-files --stage -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git show 29fdbfdab2573936bf25f93dc9d00e36c3079920
> git ls-files --stage -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git cat-file -s a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
> git cat-file -s a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb

issue.title: Untitled files sometimes remain open in the background
issue.body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Version 1.27.2 (1.27.2)
- OS Version: macOS 10.13.6 (17G65)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new untitled tab. 
2. Type something in it. 
3. Close it, and it will tell you there are still unsaved changes. Choose `Don't save`.
4. Sometimes, the `1` badge will still appear on the `Explorer` icon, indicating that the unsaved document is still open in the background.

This occurs to me about once a day. I notice it when I close a workspace, and it notifies me that there are still unsaved changes, yet I can't see any, except for the badge. I frequently open new untitled tabs, type something in them, then close them, without saving. 

It's very difficult to pinpoint the cause. It seems to matter at what point I close the tab. 

The problem may *possibly* occur when I close the document and the `Git` icon is showing the `refresh` badge. Since the `refresh` badge appears for less than a second, and perhaps once every minute or so, it's hard to reproduce this event purposely, yet the event of closing an unsaved document and this badge appearing occurs pretty frequent on a daily basis, by accident.

I've had this bug for months, perhaps about three months or more.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

comment.body: No, this bug is that occasionally, when I close an untitled file, the dirty counter does not go down. It is very difficult to reproduce. Like I said, I've noticed that the dirty icon on the Explorer icon will sometimes "refresh" (disappear then re-appear), and if I close an untitled document at the exact same time, then the untitled document seems to remain open in the background.

issue.title: ripgrep (rg.exe) downloading all my offline files from onedrive
issue.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.29
- OS Version: Windows 10 (1809)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Since updating to the latest version of VSCode I have started getting a notification that rg.exe is downloading files from OneDrive. The result is that all my offline files try to get downloaded and this results in my HDD running out of space.

The first time it happened I marked the files as offline only (using clear space) and the files were deleted from the local PC, but then the issue happened again the next time I opened VSCode. I did a search through the computer file system and the only instance of rg.exe on my machine is the one bundled with VSCode. 

I have now uninstalled the app to keep the problem from coming back.

I can only assume that ripgrep is traversing the local file system for some reason and attempting to open all the files which will trigger the download of offline files. I cannot imagine why VS Code would need/want to search through the entire file system.

issue.title: auto complete needs restarting
issue.body:

issue.title: Add contributes.html.customTags and contributes.html.customAttributes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Continuation of #62976.

These contribution points should be similar to the user configurations:

```json
{
  "html.experimental.custom.tags": [
    "./web-components.json",
    "./element-details/web-components.json"
  ],
  "html.experimental.custom.attributes": [
    "./web-component-attributes.json"
  ]
}
```

They allow extension authors to publish a list of tags / attributes together with its frameworks, and VS Code could load them for HTML language features.

issue.title: Should be able to search for \r in editor find
issue.body:
- Have file with CRLF line endings
- Search for `foo\n` as regex
- Get match ✔️ this is ok, people want to search in their editor without thinking about line endings, and we shouldn't change this, it could confuse people
- Search for `foo\r\n` as regex
- No match 🐛 but it should match, because some people want to specify the \r, and since it works in text search, we should be consistent.

As discussed, this is now possible to support with the editor buffer changes

issue.title: Manually Label New Windows
issue.body:
As a regular user of VSCode I would love the ability to manually label windows. 

## Use case:  
I have a working window with a series of directories and all sorts of tabs. Let's say I'm developing a large application.

I open a new window as a scratch pad for something I want to remember that's outside of the context of the development.

A coworker asks for help on a project.  I open a 3rd window and open the working directory to begin helping them.

Given 3 windows now all named VSCode it would be easier to distinguish them in my desktop if they were labeled something specific.

## Current State
Right now each window displays the current opened file

issue.title: [Extension API] window.showQuickPick with { canPickMany: true } option has the wrong return type
issue.body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.29.1
- OS Version: MacOS Mojave 10.14.1

Steps to Reproduce:

The return type for `showQuickPick` depends on the type of the first argument. For simplicity, in the code snippets below, I'm just using `vscode.QuickPickitem` as my type, but the behaviour is of course the same for any object implementing this interface.

Since the user can select multiple items for this QP, I want to be able to capture those items in an array. So I would expect the following to work:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8888438/49244932-f98f2f80-f3de-11e8-88df-267511459932.png)

However, the return type doesn't match this. The return type is always declared as 1 QuickPickItem (or undefined).

I change my code so that it can compile (just changed the typing of `selection`)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8888438/49244734-81c10500-f3de-11e8-8029-eadd2c4084cd.png)

At runtime, however, an array is in fact returned (whether I select 1 or multiple items):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8888438/49244537-095a4400-f3de-11e8-96dd-eb11020baaea.png)

So if I want to call Array methods on `selection`, I have to mark it as "any" type and use `as` :(

In terms of potential solutions:
I'm still pretty new to TypeScript, but I would be shocked to learn that it's possible to change the return type of this function depending on the `canPickMany` option :)
Maybe the team already discussed adding a new function like `window.showMultiQuickPick` with the correct return type, but decided this solution was better for simplicity despite this shortcoming. I would be OK with that, but I wanted to bring attention to this in case you all weren't aware.

comment.body: Sorry, realizing now I probably should have raised this against https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-vscode

issue.title: Rejected promises with error msg from definition provider don't get shown to the user
issue.body: - VSCode Version: Both latest Stable and Insiders Steps to Reproduce: 1. Have an extension that registers a definition provider that always returns a rejected promise with an error message 2. Trigger the `Go to definition` command on a file for which the above provider was registered 3. You will see the standard `No definition found for ...` The detailed error message from the extension is never shown. One would think that the developer console would show the message, but that only shows Logs in the output channel for Extension Host don't show any errors. The one for "Window" has the below

comment.body:
Yes, the design to not show it explicitly is understandable, but not showing the same in the Dev Tools console is not. We used to show these errors in the console, but not anymore. That's why I logged the issue.

The `onUnexpectedExternalError` part of the code hasnt been touched in ages, so I have a feeling that something else is causing this.

Currently, the `An unknown error occurred. Please consult the log for more details.` is not helpful as there is no log to consult.

issue.title: Editor: scroll jumps randomly (related to Chrome, Electron, xinput)
issue.body:
- VSCode Version: starting at 1.13.0, up to current
- OS Version: Fedora 24-27

Looks like VS Code is listening to mouse scroll events, even while it is not active in the window.
Related: 
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=608246
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=807187


**Steps to Reproduce**
requirements: Browser (Chromium / Firefox / Google Chrome), VSCode Editor (Any file type. Ideally a long file to ensure the scroll is visible.)

VSCode: Leave cursor at top of file.
Browser: Scroll, excessively, (For a few seconds) down the page. Even if it's a blank tab with no content.
VSCode: Scroll, ever so slightly, in any direction.
You'll find the editor will jump suddenly further down the active file.

It seems VSCode is receiving the scroll events, for whatever reason; which are all suddenly evaluated upon any form of scroll input in the editor.

comment.body: in ubuntu 18.04 and latest vscode, after alt+tab to opera, alt+tab to vscode editor scrolls down to bottom or top document.

issue.title: Markdown transition to Common Mark breaks YAML front matter
issue.body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.29.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.13.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. add 3 dashes to start of `.md` file
2. add yaml content
3. add another 3 dashes

The `markdown.previewFrontMatter` does nothing now and the syntax highlighting is all messed up.

comment.body:
Unsure what you mean by "insiders" but the syntax highlighting changed on a recent release of VS Code. No idea how to pinpoint which release but definitely within the last month.

Looks to be a non-issue though since question mark is not allowed in general by the YAML spec. So we can go ahead and close this issue methinks.

Just interesting is all.

@RMacfarlane the change looks good to me except for this piece that scares me. Are we sure we are not sending arbitrary data to all actions that get executed that might expect something else here? There is only one action where we need this for (Start Debug) but for any action that is triggered we now pass the args on. This has the potential of breaking badly.

pull_request.title: Support debugging process from the process explorer
pull_request.body:
Adds a 'Debug' context menu item for processes that can be attached to in the process explorer. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/63147

The issue service that communicates with the process explorer window lives in the main process, and the debug service is only in the renderer process. To start debugging, the issue service sends a `vscode:runAction` message to the renderer with the workbench debug start action id. To pass the debug config, I tweaked the `vscode:runAction` listener to pass through arguments to executeCommand. I also had to make a change to the workbench command handler to pass the argument, let me know if this looks reasonable.

pull_request.title: Support debugging process from the process explorer
pull_request.body:
Adds a 'Debug' context menu item for processes that can be attached to in the process explorer. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/63147

The issue service that communicates with the process explorer window lives in the main process, and the debug service is only in the renderer process. To start debugging, the issue service sends a `vscode:runAction` message to the renderer with the workbench debug start action id. To pass the debug config, I tweaked the `vscode:runAction` listener to pass through arguments to executeCommand. I also had to make a change to the workbench command handler to pass the argument, let me know if this looks reasonable.

issue.title: VS Code causes entire system to lag and freeze
issue.body:
Recently I updated VS code to the latest version (stable version).
Now when ever I open the VS Code the CPU usage hits 100% !!! and the entire system starting hanging.
It drops back to normal value after some 30 secs.

**Here is the interesting part:**
**When I try to build my react app using npm from the integrated terminal (powerShell), the system hits 100% CPU usage again. And now the system is not at all responsive for 10-15mins.**

**I have also tried to build my App from outside VS code and everything works fine. The app gets built in 2-3mins and system does not lag.**

This was not the problem with the earlier versions.

And nope its not a problem with my system. I am running a brand new core i7pro windows machine. 

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
-> Disabled almost all the extensions that I had installed.

Version: 1.28.1 (system setup)
Commit: 3368db6750222d319c851f6d90eb619d886e08f5
Date: 2018-10-11T18:13:53.910Z
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome: 61.0.3163.100
Node.js: 8.9.3
V8: 6.1.534.41
Architecture: x64

comment.body:
According to the process tree the only process taking CPU 26% (1 core in a quad core machine?) is the node process running in your powershell session.

```
    0       74   21396         C:\WINDOWS\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe
    0        4   60344           C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe /c ""C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.cmd" run buildwin"
    0       33   55580             electron_node npm-cli.js
    0        4   58764               electron_node min.js
    0       23   59436                 node   "reactjs" build
   26      257   59924                   node 
```

We have no control over this process as it's part of your build chain. Not sure why this wouldn't happen when build outside but you can clearly see that the node process you launched is the one causing the issues.

Can you imagine looking for a car keys when you hold them in your hand? (I mean, that could happen but it's usually a user mistake).

issue.title: Error hover semantic information should be rendered separate of error message
issue.body:
From @octref in #62159

> This is a regression on the diagnostics display.
> 
> 1.28:
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/47816972-b83d2e80-dd11-11e8-92ea-97763e51688e.png)
> 
> Insiders:
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/47817088-00f4e780-dd12-11e8-8b0c-2d45c561fbf4.png)
> 
> In both case, the diagnostics returned are:
> 
> ```js
> const diagnostics = {
>   code: "unknownProperties",
>   source: "css.lint.unknownProperties",
>   message: "Unknown property: 'foo1'"
> }
> ```

If we have access to semantic information we should render it much better. The message should come first. Then the source on a separate line, with a `Source:` label preceding it and in non-monospace font (since source should be a user-readable string like `CSS Lint`). Then, the code with the same style, but with monospace, since code is often a library/OS error code. Something like:

> `Unknown property: 'foo1'`
>
> **Source:** CSS Lint
> **Code:** `unknownProperties`

cc @sandy081  @ramya-rao-a @misolori

comment.body: In the UX call yesterday we discussed both of those options and even though we all liked both versions, we all agreed that we liked the cleaner look of last one (the one that's now on insiders).
